Question regarding using the blood plasma of recovered people to treat sick people: When the plasma is injected, is it just the antibodies in the donated plasma that attacks the virus, or does the body detect the antibodies and create more ?

Convalescent‑plasma therapy is a form of passive immunisation.

1. What is being transfused  
   • Plasma is the cell‑free part of blood, so it contains antibodies (mainly IgG, some IgM/IgA), complement proteins, clotting factors and other soluble molecules—but no B‑cells, T‑cells or other white cells that could go on making antibody.  

2. What those antibodies do after infusion  
   • Immediately circulate and bind the virus or virus‑infected cells.  
   • Neutralise the virus (block its entry into new cells).  
   • Opsonise the virus, making it easier for the patient’s phagocytes to engulf it.  
   • Activate complement or mediate antibody‑dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).

   All of this is a direct, “ready‑made” attack by the donor antibodies. They start working within minutes to hours, and their activity lasts only as long as the antibodies remain in the patient’s body (IgG half‑life ≈ 21 days).

3. Does the recipient then make more of the same antibody?  
   • No. Antibodies are not blueprints that the immune system can copy.  
   • A person’s B‑cells are “programmed” by exposure to antigen, not by exposure to someone else’s antibody. Because the transfused plasma contains virtually no B‑cells, there is nothing in it that can seed new antibody production.  
   • The patient may still develop (or continue to develop) their own antibody response to the virus because they are infected and are seeing viral antigens, but that response is independent of the transfused antibodies.

4. Indirect help to the patient’s own immune response  
   • By lowering the amount of free virus, the donor antibodies can give the patient’s immune system time to catch up and mount its own response.  
   • Immune complexes formed by donor antibodies bound to virus can enhance antigen presentation, which may slightly boost the patient’s own antibody production.  
   • Nevertheless, any antibodies the patient eventually produces are generated de novo by their own B‑cells; they are not “copies” expanded from the transfused antibodies.

5. Duration and comparison with a vaccine  
   • Passive immunity: immediate but temporary; no immunological memory.  
   • Active immunity (vaccine or surviving the infection): slower to appear but long‑lasting and memory‑forming.

So, in short, the therapeutic benefit of convalescent plasma comes almost entirely from the donor antibodies acting directly against the virus. The patient’s body does not “learn” from those antibodies or manufacture more of them; it must still mount its own immune response to gain lasting protection.

CMV: NFTs are digital garbage whose popularity is fueled by greedy speculation. We’ve seen this before… Hummel figurines, beanie babies, Thomas Kinkade ‘collectibles’. People will compete to spend money on tokens purely out of speculation under the misguided belief that “These are gonna be worth something someday.” With NFTs, I don’t believe there is any true value to them and as a medium, I do not believe they will have lasting artistic significance.   My current take is that NFTs are an offshoot of what I’ll deem “The Blockchain Bubble”. When I googled “What makes an NFT valuable?” I got this: “Factors that make NFTs such a valuable investment are utility, ownership history, underlying value, perception of the buyer, liquidity premium and future value”  All of this is subjective with a heavy profit motive, but the profit hinges on speculation not retailing or commodities.   People compare owning an NFT to owning an original painting or the Masters of a recording. The problem with this is - those products can be commoditized while an NFT can not.   Moreover, NFTs are not competitive in the digital ecosystem - there are literally BILLIONS of drawings paintings pictures songs and depictions that are free, all over the internet. They aren’t scarce or limited - so why would I want to pay for something when I can obtain it for free?   We are in the middle of a hype-cycle and humans flock towards the next shiny thing like magpies… but I concede there may be more to this than I realize. Maybe there is something about NFTs that is valuable… change my view!

I agree with you that 2021–22 was a textbook asset‑bubble and that most of the pictures sold as “NFT art” will never recover the prices people paid for them.  
But the fact that a first wave of use‑cases was dominated by FOMO and greed does not imply that the technical primitive itself is pointless.  Below are a few angles that tend to survive careful scrutiny, even once you strip away the hype.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Digital scarcity can create real economic value
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Scarcity already exists for purely digital objects that are easy to copy: Internet domain names, Twitter / Instagram handles, Steam game skins, airline miles, World of Warcraft gold, etc.  Technically anyone can copy the string “google.com”, but only one wallet can hold the actual DNS registration.  That exclusivity is why the name is valuable.

• An NFT is nothing more than a registry entry on a public database (a blockchain) that says “wallet X controls identifier Y”.  If the underlying identifier has utility, the market will price it as such, exactly as with domain names.

• The NFT standard is open and permissionless, so rather than hundreds of fragmented, proprietary registries—each controlled by one company—you get a single, composable ledger.  This greatly lowers switching costs and increases liquidity (easier to buy, sell, collateralize, borrow against, etc.).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Authenticity and provenance for digital media
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Before NFTs, the only way to tell whether a .jpg really came from Beeple, Pak, or the NBA was to trust a centralized site (Dropbox, NBA.com, etc.) or to rely on watermarks that could be forged.  
  – With NFTs, Beeple can upload a hash of the file that’s permanently tied to his public key.  Anyone can now cryptographically verify: “Yes, this object originated from Beeple.”  Museums and auction houses already do this for physical art; NFTs are simply the first generally‑workable solution for natively digital work.

• Royalties.  You can debate whether 5–10 % “creator royalties” should be enforceable forever, but the technical fact is that NFTs made it trivial for artists to code resale royalties into the asset itself.  That’s a genuine improvement over the legacy art market, where the original artist usually earns $0 when a painting flips for $10 M years later.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Composability unlocks new business models
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because all NFTs live on the same open ledger, any developer can write software that recognizes or extends any other NFT without asking permission.

• Tickets and memberships  
  – Coachella, UEFA and several major U.S. sports teams have already piloted NFTs as tickets.  They eliminate counterfeiting, can automatically split resale fees between the team and the performer, and double as perpetual “proof‑of‑attendance” collectibles.  
  – Bored Ape Yacht Club holders got access to private Discords, merch drops, ApeFest concerts, and even an IP license to use the Ape in commercial products.  Strip away the monkey pictures; what remains is simply a transferable membership credential that any third‑party business can recognize.

• In‑game items  
  – Counter‑Strike skins and Fortnite dances already trade for thousands of dollars, but they’re locked to Valve/Epic servers.  NFTs let the *player* hold the key.  If the studio shuts down, the asset can still live on and appear in new games because the data is open.

• Decentralized finance (DeFi)  
  – People are already borrowing stablecoins against high‑end NFTs (Art Blocks, Punks) the same way you would borrow against a piece of real estate.  Whether you personally want to do that is beside the point; the fact that it’s possible—with no bank, broker or lawyer—is new.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4. “But anyone can right‑click–save…”
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Owning the bytes and owning the *claim* are different things—exactly the same distinction that makes the PDF of the Mona Lisa worthless while the original under glass at the Louvre is invaluable.

• Social signaling.  A Lamborghini can be replicated in a video game, but people still pay for the real one because the *certificate of authenticity* matters.  In online environments (Twitter profile pics, metaverse spaces, etc.) an NFT’s blockchain receipt is that certificate.

• Legal rights.  In several jurisdictions, the NFT itself is now accepted evidence in court for IP licensing or chain‑of‑title disputes.  Prada, LVMH and Cartier co‑founded the “Aura” consortium to mint NFTs that prove the authenticity of their handbags and watches.  That is, literally, anti‑counterfeiting infrastructure.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5. Environmental & scalability criticisms are not fatal
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Most new NFT volume has moved from proof‑of‑work chains (Ethereum 1.0) to proof‑of‑stake chains (Ethereum 2.0, Solana, Tezos, Polygon).  The Merge cut Ethereum’s energy use by ~99.95 %.  Minting an NFT on modern chains has a smaller carbon footprint than sending two emails with large attachments.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6. Historical precedent: bubbles ≠ useless
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Railroads (1840s), radio (1920s), dot‑coms (1990s) and smartphones (2000s) each had speculative manias, followed by crashes, followed by durable, transformative businesses.  Pets.com went to zero, but Amazon, eBay and PayPal emerged from the same frenzy.

• Beanie Babies are a closer analogy to a single brand of collectible than to an open, general‑purpose data primitive.  A better analogy for NFTs is TCP/IP or the DNS standard.  Most early dot‑com domain names were registered purely to flip, yet the DNS system clearly has lasting utility.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7. What an NFT is *not*
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• It is not the image or song itself (unless the file is fully on‑chain; most aren’t).  
• It is not a promise of future price appreciation (that’s just speculation).  
• It is not, by itself, a shortcut to mass adoption; just like email was useless until enough people had email addresses, many NFT use‑cases require critical mass.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Your skepticism about short‑term price mania is spot‑on.  Roughly 95 % of the JPEG‑flipping market will die off, and thousands of bands, athletes and brands are indeed slapping “NFT” on junk just to make a quick buck.

What *survives* will be the underlying primitive: a globally readable, permissionless ledger for unique digital objects.  That primitive already:

• solves authenticity and provenance for digital media,  
• enables transferable, programmable memberships and tickets,  
• gives players true ownership of in‑game items,  
• lets creators bake royalties and licensing rules directly into the asset, and  
• creates a composable base layer on which any developer can build without asking permission.

None of those functions depend on tulip‑like price charts—which is why, even after this bubble deflates, NFTs (or whatever we call the standard in five years) are likely to keep turning up in products you use.

You may still feel that *owning* a PFP‑monkey is silly; that’s a matter of personal taste.  But the mechanism that makes that monkey provably scarce and interoperable is the same mechanism that’s already improving ticketing, fashion anti‑counterfeiting, generative art, and digital identity.  Dismissing the entire concept as “digital garbage” risks throwing out a genuinely useful protocol with the bath‑water of speculation.

What judgment should I make when I encounter claims that have neither supporting evidence nor counterevidence? Suppose someone claims that a unicorn exists, and there is no evidence for or against the existence of a unicorn, what should a rational thinker do in such scenario?  Should one suspend judgment? Or should one reason that the claim is more likely to be false since it is a better explanation in terms of simplicity?

1. The three doxastic options  
Whenever you meet a proposition p (“Unicorns exist”) you have only three possible epistemic attitudes toward it.  
A. Believe p (accept it as true)  
B. Disbelieve p (accept ¬p, i.e. that unicorns do not exist)  
C. Suspend judgment (withhold belief both ways)

The rational attitude is the one that is best supported by your total evidence.  

2. No evidence ⇒ no positive justification  
If literally nothing counts for or against p, believing p would violate the classical evidentialist maxim (Locke, Hume, Clifford): “Proportion belief to the evidence.” There is nothing to proportion a positive belief to, so option A is ruled out.

3. Should we then disbelieve or suspend?  

a) Pure agnosticism:  
If you interpret “no evidence” very strictly—no background knowledge whatsoever that bears on the issue—then neither p nor ¬p is evidentially favored, and suspension (C) is rational. This is the stance Huxley labeled “agnostic.”

b) Real‑world context: background information is evidence  
In practice we never reason in a vacuum. We know a great deal about biology, zoology, fossils, genetics, and about how often comparably extraordinary entities have turned up in well‑searched domains (never). All of that is indirect but genuine evidence and it strongly favors ¬p.  

Bayesian statement:  
Prior(“an as‑yet unknown, horse‑like mammal with a single horn exists somewhere”) is very small because:  
• It postulates extra, unobserved structure (Occam’s razor penalizes complexity).  
• Billions of observations of large land animals have revealed none that fit the description.  

Because the prior is already tiny, and nothing new has been observed, the posterior probability of p remains tiny. That is enough to license practical disbelief—treat p as almost certainly false—while still being ready to revise if serious evidence appears.

4. “Absence of evidence” vs. “evidence of absence”  
When a domain has been thoroughly looked into, not finding the posited entity is itself evidence of absence. Russell’s teapot, Sagan’s invisible dragon, and the unicorn all fall in that class. Failure to detect them, given our ability and history of detecting similar things, is real counter‑evidence, not a mere absence of evidence.

5. Where simplicity comes in  
Occam’s razor is not a tiebreaker after all other factors are equal; it is one of the evidential factors. More complex hypotheses receive lower prior probability, which rationally tilts us toward ¬p even before direct observations are made.

6. Summary  
– If literally nothing bears on the question, rationality requires suspension of judgment.  
– In any realistic case, abundant background evidence plus the simplicity principle heavily favors the negation, so the rational stance is to withhold acceptance of p and, for all practical purposes, treat p as false while remaining open to revision should credible evidence arrive.
